MERGER (SINGAPORE/FEDERATION OF MALAYA)
(White Paper)


2.32 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [21st November, 1961] to Question [20th November, 1961],

    "That, whereas it has always been the avowed objective of all nationalists of Malaya to achieve the reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya and to remove the artificial division created by the British by their policy of "divide and rule", this House affirms and declares that the first objective of all true patriots of Malaya is to achieve the reunification of these two territories in a merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya.".-(The Minister for Labour-Inche Ahmad bin Ibrahim).

    Which Amendment was,

    'To leave out from "a" in the second last line to the end and insert:

    "genuine merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya, with Singapore entering the Federation as the twelfth State and with all its Citizens automatically becoming Federal citizens on Merger Day".'-(Dr Lee Siew Choh).

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

2.34 p.m.

Column: 1368



    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the adjournment was taken last night, I was on the question of citizenship and Singapore citizens. To put the matter in its proper perspective, perhaps you might allow me to go into the question of Singapore citizenship and how Singapore citizenship is acquired, because one of the difficulties that the people of Singapore are facing over the question of merger is what will happen to them as Singapore citizens when these so-called constitutional arrangements have been effected. It is not only an important constitutional issue, but even more important from the public point of view, it seems to be an emotional issue. Therefore, it is only fair that this question is completely and fully ventilated in this Assembly.

    As I understand Singapore citizenship. Mr Speaker, Sir, it is possible to acquire it under four heads:

    (1) You become a Singapore citizen by birth;

    (2) You become a Singapore citizen by descent;

    (3) You become a Singapore citizen by registration; and

    (4) You become a Singapore citizen by naturalization.

Once a person has acquired Singapore citizenship under any of these categories, he is a Singapore citizen, and so far as he is concerned and so long as he remains a Singapore citizen, he has absolutely equal rights. Singapore citizens all have absolutely equal rights one with the other. There is absolutely no question that there is any difference between a Singapore citizen by birth and a Singapore citizen by registration, descent, or naturalization. There is only one difference between these four categories of citizens. First, Mr Speaker. Sir, I would like to emphasize the word "categories" of citizens and not "classes" of citizens. They are not "classes" of citizens, but "categories" of citizens, depending on the manner in which citizenship is acquired. Having acquired it, they are equal and the same in the eyes of the law, constitutionally or

Column: 1369

otherwise. But there is one important distinction between a citizen by birth and a citizen by descent on the one hand, and a citizen by registration and a citizen by naturalization on the other. Whereas it would be impossible for the Government to deprive a citizen by birth or by descent of his citizenship, it would be possible for the Government to deprive a citizen by naturalization or by registration if the citizen in these latter categories should behave himself in a manner contrary to the interests of the State. That is not a provision peculiar to Singapore. It is a provision which every civilised country has in its laws, because it is only right that when a person is given the privilege of becoming a citizen of a State, he should continue to behave in a manner which will not be to the detriment of the State. Therefore, quite rightly, every civilised State has reserved unto itself the right to deprive a citizen by naturalization or by registration of his citizenship if he should misbehave. That, Mr Speaker, Sir, does not make him a second-class citizen nor a third-class citizen. Mr Speaker, Sir, I am a Singapore citizen by registration, having been born in the Federation. I do not, for one moment, consider myself a second-class citizen. My status in the eyes of the law and so far as my rights are concerned are absolutely co-equal with those of a person born in Singapore or of a person whose parent was a Singapore citizen and who was born outside Singapore.

    Having sketched that, Mr Speaker, then the question arises whether amongst Singapore citizens themselves there is inequality. There is absolutely no inequality. If anybody in Singapore is putting out the proposition that although there are different categories of citizens by virtue of the fact that there are different categories of citizenship, therefore, there are different classes of citizenship, that is an absolute lie calculated to do a great deal of emotional harm, and the motives behind putting out such a proposition cannot be strictly honourable.

    When these constitutional arrangements go through, Singapore citizens will

Column: 1370

remain Singapore citizens, and there can be no question that I am going to be a second class citizen. I am absolutely convinced of that. My category is the same as the category of citizens who were born in China or India or Ceylon or any other part of the world, and who, by virtue of adequate residence in Singapore, has acquired citizenship by registration. What happens to me and to people like me who were not born in the Federation but outside the Federation, say, in China, or India or Ceylon or any other part of the world, is this - that we will all remain Singapore citizens and exercise our rights as Singapore citizens in any constitutional arrangements that will have been arrived at between the Federation Government and ourselves. What will then be the net result so far as Singapore citizenship is concerned after -

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Merger.

    Mr Rajah: - merger, as the Minister for Finance likes to call it? Mr Speaker, Sir, as I understand the position, it will be this, that when the State Assembly elections are conducted, I will be allowed a vote; and when the Federal elections are conducted - and for that purpose, I take it, if it is going to be 15 seats, the island of Singapore will be divided into 15 electoral divisions, or wards as the case may be - and if I should so desire, I can offer myself for election. What is more, I can vote for myself, if I choose to stand in the ward where my name appears on the register. Where then does the proposition propounded by the Barisan Sosialis come in about second-class citizenship? If the proposition is that a Singapore citizen becomes a second-class citizen by virtue of the fact that he is not allowed to vote in the Federation or to stand for election in the Federation, and if that and that only is the reason for stating the proposition that Singapore citizens are second-class citizens, then might I suggest to the Barisan Sosialis, if they look at it from the Federation point of view, that a Federal citizen could equally say then that because he is not allowed to stand for election in Singapore or

Column: 1371

to vote in Singapore, he himself is a second-class citizen. The proposition is too absurd to be contemplated. Why then do we labour the point that the Singapore citizen is inferior to the Federal citizen? Can it be that my friend, the Member for Queenstown, has a complex about himself? Has he a complex that a Singapore citizen is inferior to a Federal citizen? Mr Speaker, Sir, I myself have no such complex. I feel that I am equal to the Federal citizen, if not superior. And why should I not feel it if I am so inclined to feel it? I do not think the Federation Prime Minister is going to object to my thinking that I am superior and that Singapore citizenship is superior to Federal citizenship. It is a matter of opinion and I am entitled to mine. But if the Barisan Sosialis propounds as a fact that Singapore citizenship is inferior to Federal citizenship, that, Mr Speaker, Sir, is not true. It is not correct.

    I was rung up this morning by a number of people. They said, "We were very glad you clarified this point because we were in doubt." A further point was asked of me: can a Singapore citizen sit in the Federal Parliament? I said, "Surely you have read the White Paper; surely it has all been explained." It is amazing, Mr Speaker, Sir, the amount of ignorance there is in Singapore about these matters, and as a result of this ignorance, a lot of misunderstandings are current. I said, "Of course, if you feel so inclined, if you wish to stand for election to the Federal Parliament, you will be entitled to do so. There is nothing in the White Paper which I can see which goes against it. In fact, if I remember rightly, Mr Speaker, Sir, there is an express statement to that effect. In paragraph 14, page 4 of Paper Cmd. 33 of 1961, it reads:

    'Singapore citizens will vote in Singapore for their representatives to the new Federation Parliament and the citizens of the present Federation of Malaya will vote in the present Federation for their representatives to the same new Federation Parliament.'

Column: 1372

From that paragraph it seems to me obvious that Singapore citizens will vote and can stand in Singapore in respect of the 15 constituencies which will send their representatives to the Federal Parliament. Even from that point of view, there is no question of a second-class citizenship.

    A further question was raised whether the words "Federal national" have been introduced into these proceedings with a view to confusing the issues and that a Federal national is not really a Federal national; he might be a British subject, and, therefore, being a British subject it is something derogatory. I think it was the Member for Anson who took the view that a Federal national really equates to a British subject. Mr Speaker, Sir, all that the White Paper says is this. A Singapore citizen and a Federal citizen will both become Federal nationals. At the moment the phrase "Federal national" is not known to the Constitution of the Federation of Malaya. I take it that it will be necessary to amend the Constitution to give the phrase a place in the statute. I take it that it will be done. Once that is done, then the term "Federal national" has a constitutional significance, and under the Federation Constitution, a Federal national will be a Commonwealth citizen and not a British subject. The British are wise people. They amended their British Nationality Laws - I think it was in 1947 or 1948; I cannot remember the exact date - because, in their wisdom, they knew that the term "British subject" was not viewed with favour by people in the Dominions, and therefore they devised an arrangement under their British Nationality Laws and coined a new phrase "Commonwealth citizen". So that a Federal national will become a Commonwealth citizen. Now a Commonwealth citizen will have the status of a British subject. Therefore, the Member for Anson argued that if he has the status of a British subject, he is then a British subject. With great respect to the Member for Anson - he is my senior in many ways - I beg to disagree with him. Having the status of a British subject does not necessarily mean that you are

Column: 1373

a British subject. What it means is this, that if you should happen to be in Great Britain, then having the status of a British subject would entitle you to all the privileges that a British subject would enjoy in the British Isles. That is all it means, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    If I may make my point clearer and bring it home to the Member for Anson. Recently we have read in the papers that Japanese nationals will be given the status of South Africans in South Africa when they are in South Africa. I ask the Member for Anson, does he, in all seriousness, advance the argument that because of this that Japanese nationals will become south African subjects? I think the Japanese people will be the first to disavow it. What it merely means is this. If Japanese nationals have been given by the South African Government in their wisdom the status of South Africans in South Africa, it merely means that they can ride with the whites in their buses; and if the Japanese want it that way, they are welcome to it. Why should we object?

    I also understand from the papers that the People's Republic of China has applied for that status. Both the extreme Right and the extreme Left in Asia want the status of South Africans, and if they want it, Mr Speaker, Sir, who are we to say that it is a derogatory status? But the curious position is this. We have heard a lot about the Afro-Asian conferences. It is a bit peculiar when two nations in Asia - one on the extreme Right and the other on the extreme Left - should seek the status of South Africans. So it is difficult to know where we are in this modern world. The extreme Right and the extreme Left want to ride in the same bus as a South African, but they do not want to ride with their black brothers. So when we talk about Socialism and the extreme Right, I, as one who does not subscribe to any such particular political philosophy, am a bit confused. But that is only by the way.

    Therefore, Mr Speaker, Sir, let us not say that a Singapore citizen is a second-class citizen. Let us not even go one

Column: 1374

better and say third-class citizens. This category was introduced yesterday. The point was made that a Federal citizen is a first-class citizen, a Singapore citizen is a second-class citizen. Yesterday the point was made that there are third-class citizens. The point and purpose of that statement was to draw a difference between Singapore citizens by birth and by registration. According to some Members of the Barisan Sosialis, it seems that citizens by registration are third-class citizens, and in that category is your humble servant. I do not accept that statement. It is not true. It is not right. I would like Members of the Barisan Sosialis to quote chapter and verse because I am personally vitally interested in that issue, because if any constitutional arrangement arrived at by the Hon, the Prime Minister with the Federation Prime Minister were to make me into a third-class citizen, I would be the first to object to it.

    An hon. Member: You have an alliance with the P.A.P.!

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): We are no citizens at all in the Federation.

    Mr Speaker: Order. If hon. Members wish for elucidation, all they have to do is to stand up and I am sure the Member for Farrer Park will oblige.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I have made any mis-statements on the law, if I have misconceived the position, if I have made any wrong statements to this House, if any Member, either on the Front Benches or on the Back Benches on the Government side or on the Front Benches or on the Back Benches on the Opposition side, says I am talking nonsense and I am wrong in any of my statements, I am quite prepared to give way so that the House will be given a full explanation, of the true factual and legal position resulting from these constitutional arrangements. I await that, Mr Speaker, Sir, and I will gladly resume my seat and give them the Floor.

    An hon. Member: Hear, hear!

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not wish to stay very much longer on the

Column: 1375

Floor. There are other important issues to be discussed and I hope I am confining myself strictly to the amendment. I will have something more to say when the main motion is debated.

    On the adjournment yesterday, I was fumbling around with the Wartawan to find a statement made by Mr Lim Ching Siong, the Secretary-General of the Barisan Sosialis, to the effect that he and his Party were willing to go to the people of Singapore to explain to them the whole position and obtain their support. Now that is a tall statement for anyone to make. For one person to say that he can convince the people of Singapore, I envy him if he can do that. But if he exercises that power in the right direction, he will do a power of good for this country and I have every confidence that his intention is to do a power of good to this country. But to put the record clear and right, let me quote him:

    'We are fully aware of the difficulties that face us in our struggle for Malayan unity. As a result of colonial rule, differences of race and religion have been emphasised and much work will be needed to repair the damage done by colonialism. However, we declare that if the representatives of the people of the Federation are agreeable to do the same-'

this is the place, Mr Speaker, Sir:

    'we will pledge ourselves to exert whole-heartedly our influence to win the people of Singapore to accept full and complete merger forthwith, that is, with Singapore as the twelfth State of the Federation and with Singapore citizens automatically becoming Malayan citizens with proportional representation in the Federation Parliament. Let the Government of the Federation of Malaya tell us if it is prepared to persuade the people of the Federation to accept the people of Singapore in a full and complete merger before 1963.'

Now let us examine the psychological situation against which such a statement is made.

    Mr David Marshall: On a point of elucidation, Sir.

    Mr Rajah resumed his seat.

    Mr David Marshall: I am sorry to intervene at this stage. I thought the Member was going on with the question of citizenship. Would the speaker agree - I have

Column: 1376

not got the documents with me but I have quoted them - that in the Constitution of the Federation of Malaya there is an express provision that only Federal citizens may sit both in the House and in the Senate, and in the White Paper it is perfectly consistent with our voting for Federal citizens who will then represent us? Secondly, would the Member agree that all Commonwealth citizens under the British Nationality and Status of Aliens Act, 1948, are in fact British nationals?

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I regret the Member for Anson was not listening to me carefully. You see, Sir, how difficult it is to get a point across. How can the people in the coffee-shops understand anything when the Member for Anson, who is himself a trained lawyer, and I myself - I hope that I can say that I am a trained lawyer - used to the use of words, are trying to put words together in a manner which people will understand? If I cannot get myself across to him and he cannot get himself across to me, we can see how difficult the position of the man in the coffee-shop is. Mr Speaker, Sir, I have already told the House that at the moment the phrase "Federal national" is not known to the Federal Constitution - at least I have not seen it in the Federal Constitution. As this is a phrase coined as a result of these constitutional arrangements, it will therefore become necessary - I have told the House; I may be wrong -

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Surely it must be so.

    Mr Rajah: - it will become necessary to amend the Federal Constitution. Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson must know all this. Let us not look at the Federal Constitution as something which is going to be static. It follows the will of the people. No constitution is static. It moves with the will of the people, and if the will of the people is that this Constitution is to be amended, it will be amended; and it will be amended to this effect, that wherever the phrase "Federal citizen" appears, the phrase "Federal national" shall be substituted.

Column: 1377

That is only my suggestion. They might amend it in some other way. But certainly the Constitution must be amended to carry with it the conception of a Federal national and to give it statutory effect and legal concept. That must be done. I cannot, therefore, understand the Member for Anson saying that because the Constitution now does not have the phrase "Federal national", how can Singapore citizens sit in the Federal Assembly? If this Constitution is amended to bring in the phrase "Federal national", and because a Singapore citizen is a Federal national, therefore, by virtue of the fact that he is a Federal national, he is entitled to sit in the Federal Parliament. Surely it is a simple proposition. I would have thought that the Member for Anson would have been the first to understand it. If he cannot understand it, how much more difficult it is going to be for persons in the coffee-shops to understand it. And I beg of the Government, if they are serious in these constitutional arrangements - and they are of vital importance to the country - that they put this across to the people. They do not understand it, Mr Speaker. If the Member for Anson cannot understand it -

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: He does not want to!

    Mr Rajah: Does not want to? No, I do not say that. How can that be? He is a patriot.

    The Prime Minister: Hear hear!

    Mr David Marshall: Point of elucidation, Mr Speaker.

    Mr Rajah resumed his seat.

    Mr David Marshall: I am very much obliged. Sir, this is very important. Is the speaker, in fact, stating -

    Mr Speaker: Member.

    Mr David Marshall: I beg your pardon. Is the Member, in fact, stating that he is satisfied that wherever the words "Federal citizen" appear in the Federal Constitution, the words "Federal national" will be substituted? Because if that is so, it makes a complete change in my own stand. I am sorry I am stupid. But if I am given an assurance that

Column: 1378

wherever in the Federal Constitution the words "Federal national" appear, sections 8, 10, 82, wherever the words "Federal citizen" appear, the words "Federal national" will be substituted, I will vote for the White Paper.

    Mr Rajah: I am so glad we have now clarified the position because I am entirely with the Member for Anson. If the Constitution is not going to be amended to make me a Federal National, co-equal with a Federal citizen for purposes of sitting in the Federal Parliament, then I will certainly vote against the White Paper. Why should I vote for it? It is on that understanding and on that basis that I am supporting the White Paper. And let me tell the Member for Anson through you, Sir, that if under this Constitution there are certain things which are pertinent to the rights of man, then I sincerely hope that the rights of man in the Federation and in Singapore will be co-equal. I do sincerely hope that.

    The Prime Minister: That is so.

    Mr Rajah: That must be so. Otherwise, there can be no constitutional arrangements. There can be no equality of status. I am supporting this entirely on that basis - that the rights of man in Singapore and the rights of man in the Federation co-equate and are co-equal, and interchangeable. The Federal citizen can come here and the Singapore citizen can go there. But they cannot go into each other's territory for purposes of exercising the vote. That is the constitutional arrangement for the time being. When the psychology of the two territories changes, then possibly there need not be a Federal citizen and a Singapore citizen. But that is not possible now. Let us hope it will be within our lifetime anyway.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am almost finished, but there are one or two points I would like to stress to the House.

    Sir, there is one phrase used by the Member for Upper Serangoon.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): He is not here.

    Mr Rajah: The Member for Upper Serangoon is not here. He is such an

Column: 1379

important adjunct in the Barisan Sosialis system of things that I would have liked him to be here in order to pose this problem to him.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, when he was speaking yesterday in this House, he said this, "The people of Singapore like socialism." There is absolutely nothing wrong with that. It is the fashion nowadays to be a socialist. And who does not want to be in the fashion, whether to be in a bush jacket, without a tie, or with a tie? The three classes are well represented here, Mr Speaker.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Three classes of socialists.

    Mr Rajah: By that I do not mean three classes of citizens. They are still co-equal, I hope.

    He went on to say what struck me as something very interesting - "especially for the Chinese." Mr Speaker, this is the sort of thing that really gets me down. What is this brief "especially for the Chinese"? The Member for Thomson is not a Chinese. The Member for Bukit Timah is not a Chinese.

    Mr Speaker: The Parliamentary Secretary.

    Mr Rajah: I beg your pardon, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister is not a Chinese. Mr Devan Nair is not a Chinese.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Byrne is not a Chinese.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Byrne is not a Chinese.

    An hon. Member: The Minister for Law!

    Mr Rajah: The Minister for Law is not a Chinese.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: The Minister for Culture.

    Mr Rajah: The Minister for Culture, one of the ablest spokesmen, rather more able than the Member for Thomson, is not a Chinese. The Vice-Chairman of the Barisan Sosialis is not a Chinese.

Column: 1380



    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): The Member for Anson.

    Mr Rajah: Yes, he is not a Chinese. My Chinese friends, I hope, will forgive me if I tell them that some of the ablest spokesmen for socialism in Malaya are non-Chinese.

    The Prime Minister: Not for Communism, you know.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, why then do we draw this red herring - "especially for the Chinese"? What does the Member for Upper Serangoon mean by that? If you are a socialist, you are a socialist.

    The Prime Minister: Yes.

    Mr Rajah: And I thought that one of the basic tenets of socialism is that once you are a true socialist, you cease to be a Chinese or an Indian. You are an internationalist.

    The Prime Minister: No, that is not true after the 22nd Congress.

    Mr Rajah: I do not know about this Congress. My theory is that way back one of the basic tenets of socialism is the international creed. Once you are a socialist, you have no race, no creed, no country. Why talk about the Chinese? Mr Speaker, Sir, a socialist is not a chauvinist. And if a socialist talks like a chauvinist, what does one make of him?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is just one last thing I wish to state. The proposals before the House on the question of merger and the other allied motions that are being discussed are in the nature of temporary measures. They have not reached any form of finality. It is just an immediate step to something which we want in the future. With that intent and purpose, that seems to be the position. I give notice now that when the proper time comes, Mr Speaker, I shall move an amendment to item 3 on the Order Paper, under the name of the Hon, the Prime Minister - White Paper on Reunification of Singapore and Federation of Malaya:

    'That this House, accepts the heads of agreement set out in'

Column: 1381



    Mr David Marshall: Point of order, Mr Speaker, Sir. We are discussing the amendment. Surely we cannot at this stage, before the amendment is passed, deal with item 3?

    Mr Speaker: Order. I understood the Member for Farrer Park just to indicate what he is going to do. Of course, he will not be able to discuss his amendment now.

    Mr Rajah: Thank you, Mr Speaker. That is exactly my intention. I give notice now, after which I shall sit down.

    '...agreed to between the Governments of the State of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya as a working basis for a reunification of the two territories.'

The amendment which I intend to propose, Mr Speaker, will be this:

    After the word "That", to insert:

    "as an immediate practical step towards the ideal goal of complete merger,"

    'this House accepts the heads of agreement set out in the White Paper Cmd. 33 of 1961 agreed to between the Governments of the State of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya as a working basis for a reunification of the two territories.'

The point and purpose of the amendment, Mr Speaker, is to throw the debate into proper focus.

3.09 p.m.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish first to address myself to the amendment moved by the Member for Queenstown. There are two parts to his amendment. First, that Singapore should merge with the Federation of Malaya as the twelfth State; second, that all Singapore citizens should automatically become Federation citizens.

    May I first deal with the first limb of the amendment - that Singapore should be the twelfth State of the Federation? Let me refer him to a joint statement issued on 16th September this year by the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya and myself. That statement said:

    'The two Prime Ministers are satisfied that all legitimate local and special interests of the people in the two territories can and will be safeguarded with the merger of Singapore as a State within the Federation.'

Column: 1382

I want to emphasise these words, Sir - "merger of Singapore as a State within the Federation". These are not casual words uttered at Press Conferences or in conversations. These are words carefully chosen after scrutiny by officials of both sides. They carry with them the full import of their ordinary meaning. There can be no doubt whatsoever that Singapore will be the twelfth State of the new Federation. I do not know whether there is any special virtue in being the 12th, 13th, 14th or 15th State, but I can assure hon.
